title: 'That's what Dak says': Cowboys respond to Doug Pederson's claim Eagles are 'gonna win'
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: USA TODAY Sports' Lorenzo Reyes was on hand for the Cowboys' 24-22 loss to the Jets on Sunday and spoke with coaches and players about how they move forward from here. USA TODAY

FRISCO, Texas — Jourdan Lewis didn’t need to hear the end of the question.

He didn’t need to be told about Eagles coach Doug Pederson’s comments asserting that Philadelphia would win in Arlington this weekend to overtake the Cowboys for first place in the NFC East.

Yes, the Cowboys cornerback said, he’d heard.

“That’s fine,” Lewis told USA TODAY Sports. “You’ve still got to face an opponent and the results are still uncertain, so that’s definitely something to get his team riled up and ready to play.

“When you put your affirmations out there so confidently, you feel like it means something way more than it’s already supposed to mean.”

A Cowboys team that’s bought into Jason Garrett’s “worry about ourselves” mantra had heard, by Monday evening locker room availability, what Pederson said. The Eagles coach told Philadelphia radio station 94.1 WIP that “we’re gonna win that football game, and when we do, we’re in first place in the NFC East.” He later insisted to reporters he didn’t assure a win.

“Never said guarantee a win,” Pederson said. “I'd never do that.”

The Cowboys, in the midst of a three-game losing streak, didn’t formally discuss the comments, players said. Sure, it’s yet another element of the rivalry that “makes us come out a little bit fired up,” receiver Michael Gallup said. But did a .500 Cowboys team playing for first place in the division ahead of their bye week really need more fuel?

“If you need a coach, or anybody else, to fire you up, I don’t think you really should be playing,” Gallup said. “That’s what Dak says, really every week. We shouldn’t [need] anybody else to motivate us to be fired up. You should already have that. For me, I’m not looking for anybody to fire me up.”

Will Cowboys show Doug Pederson's comments as bulletin board material?



"We probably don’t want to share what we share with our players too much," Jason Garrett said. "We do our best when we just focus on ourselves and what we need to do to prepare to play our best football." — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 14, 2019

The Cowboys are, however, looking for answers after allowing a winless Jets team to outlast them 24-22 on Sunday. The loss followed performances that fell short in New Orleans (12-10) and at home against the Packers (34-24). They struggled against the Jets to stop the pass, to convert red-zone opportunities, to protect quarterback Dak Prescott and to catch balls. Three of Prescott’s targets dropped a combined five passes.

“I just need to catch the ball,” said Gallup, who caught one of four targets for 17 yards. “I just had three balls go right through my fingers. … Supposedly we’re supposed to be on the same page. I think we are. We’re just not executing plays.”

Michael Gallup had four catches for 48 yards in the Cowboys' loss to the Jets. (Photo: Steve Luciano, AP)

WEEK 6 WINNERS, LOSERS: Cowboys at a crossroads

'WE'VE GOTTA FIGURE THIS OUT': Cowboys left without answers after stunning loss to Jets

NFL NEWSLETTER: Sign up now to get football news delivered to your inbox

Failure to execute has been among the consistent party lines in what players, and on Monday coach Jason Garrett, deem an “inconsistent” stretch of football. Against the Packers, quarterback Dak Prescott threw three interceptions that ultimately transformed 563 offensive yards into a production that was too little, too late. Green Bay running back Aaron Jones gashed Dallas’ defense for four touchdowns — the first time the franchise had ever surrendered four scores to a running back in a single game.

Dallas didn’t turn the ball over against the Jets, and allowed a Le’veon Bell-led attack just 56 rushing yards. But the offense found new problems, including drops on a day in which their four sidelined starters included receivers Amari Cooper and Randall Cobb. The secondary allowed the Jets more touchdowns than they had scored in four weeks — including a 92-yard bomb from Sam Darnold to Robby Anderson.

The Cowboys and Garrett — who is coaching in a contract year — need answers this week and for their remaining 10 games.

But responding to Pederson with a public win guarantee in return isn’t it.

“My response is we’re excited about the challenge,” Garrett said. “Obviously they’re a great football team and we’re going to focus on ourselves and what we need to do to prepare to play our best football on Sunday night.”

Lewis agreed.

“We got to go out there and play with a fire,” he said. “We can’t talk about it anymore. Go out there as a team and be working.

“I know it feels like we’re [in] a lull. But we’re going to get back on track. I promise you we’re going to get back on track.

“You’re going to see us fight.”

Follow USA TODAY Sports’ Jori Epstein on Twitter @JoriEpstein.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: Did Doug Pederson add fuel to fire? The Dallas Cowboys aren't biting at the Philadelphia Eagles head coach saying his team was "gonna win" Sunday.
